subject: Shared data between test methods in a testcase
msgSnippet: Folks, In my test case, I have a set of testXXX methods that are order dependant.  I have been using the Junit best practices doc on
messageBody:
Folks,
In my test case, I have a set of testXXX methods that are order dependant. I have been using the
"Junit best practices" doc on
http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-12-2000/jw-1221-junit_p.html
in particular the paragraph on how to preserve order of the test methods.

I am doing this because I wnat to share data between each test method (for example my first method
tests that I can create an EJB object, the next is that I can read it, the third that I can update
it and the last that I can delete it).

I have discovered, tho that when I call testRunner on the Suite, that, whereas each method IS called
in order, there is no way for me to share data between the method calls (by using private scope
class variables). I was also surprised to see that setUp was called before each test method.

I am sharing a primary key (which is generated at run time from a database sequence) which I have no
way of knowing the value of between one test run and the next.

Code snippets are:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
public class CustomerEJBTest extends TestCase {
private Context ctx;
private int ionaid;
private Properties custInfo;

public CustomerEJBTest(String name) {
super(name);
}
public static Test suite(){
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

//Since testing CRUD of the EJB, order of tests is important,
//see the best practices doc
//http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-12-2000/jw-1221-junit_p.html
//and the section on ordering tests
suite.addTest( new CustomerEJBTest("testLookup") );
suite.addTest( new CustomerEJBTest("testCreate") );
suite.addTest( new CustomerEJBTest("testFindByPrimaryKey") );
suite.addTest( new CustomerEJBTest("testFindByEmailAddress") );
suite.addTest( new CustomerEJBTest("testUpdate") );
suite.addTest( new CustomerEJBTest("testRemove") );
return suite;
}
protected void setUp() throws Exception {
...
}
